Title: The History of the Trinity Highway: A Study in Transportation Dynamics
Description:
Although the primary focus of this thesis is a history of California 299--the Trinity Highway, I have studied the construction of that road in the context of the history of transportation between Weaverville and Humboldt Bay. The history of a transportation network is not only a history of connections between people and places but also, in this remote region, the vital link connecting wilderness with civilization.
Ever since the settlement of the Weaverville area in 1848, its residents have sought reliable transportation to Humboldt Bay's seaport and merchandise. During this period a road has connected these two places for less than half that time; only since 1923 has it been possible to travel by road from the sea inland to the seat of Trinity County. Consequently a history of the Trinity Highway must include sufficient background to explain the delay in building this route, despite the acknowledged need for such an artery by the area's residents and both local and state governments. Thus when I refer to the Trinity Highway, I am, in fact , alluding to the more general concept of a transportation link that directly connects the two areas.
This thesis attempts to accomplish the following goals: 1) present a history of the development of transportation within the Humboldt-Trinity cultural and physical landscape; iv 2) analyze the dynamics of route location with an emphasis on the construction of Highway 299; and 3) show and explain the significance of the highway on economic and cultural patterns.
A history of a road connotes a description of the labor, materials, and mechanical construction of the route. While construction techniques and problems are discussed, prefer to study the history of transportation from a more humanistic approach. By determining the needs and desires of the population in relation to actual transportation improvements over time, I can reconstruct and interpret much of the region's cultural and economic history.
While, in a sense, this thesis is a regional history, the study will be limited exclusively to the effects of transportation on the population and communities within the thoroughfare's area. Before the highway was completed in 1923, the transportation link was more diffuse, involving numerous mule trails and various attempts at constructing private toll roads and railways. Thus this thesis begins with a general description of the region's pioneering transportation, and just as the road caused travelers to funnel into a narrow path, this paper then narrows its focus and concentrates on today's Trinity Highway.
Subject: 299 ; Humboldt County ; Trinity County ; Highway ; Weaverville ; Arcata ; mining ; Geological Engineering ; Mining Engineering ; Transportation Engineering ; Urban, Community and Regional Planning

Mrs. Johnson, addressing the group, reviews briefly the work of private and public agencies in preserving the redwoods, culminating in the signing into law on October 2 at the White House of the bill establishing the Redwood National Park.

Title: Elta Cartwright
Description:
Note: First 6 minutes of part 2 is tech set-up.

Description: In the 1920s, Elta Cartwright was star of the new Women's Track team at Eureka High School, and then went on to track stardom at Humboldt State. Her athletic career culminated with winning a position on the 1928 U.S. team for the Olympic Games in Amsterdam. She was the first woman named to the U.S. Olympic Team. Elta went on to teach in local school and was inducted into the HSU Athletic Hall of Fame and served as Home Coming Queen. This video features the athlete reminiscing about her experiences while looking at memorabilia related to her time at the Olympics.

Title: Logging Protests in Humboldt County
Description:
Description: This is footage of a protest dispute in 1997 between environmental activists for the Headwaters Forest and the Sheriff's Deputies of Humboldt County, California. During three protests in the Fall of 1997, police officers swabbed pepper spray in the eyes of eight activists practicing nonviolent resistance. The action taken by the police was later judged to be excessive force and a violation of the Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution (Lundberg v. County of Humboldt)

Title: Julia Butterfly Hill workshop: Her Story
Description:
Description: Julia "Butterfly" Hill is an environmental activist best known for having lived in a 180-foot-tall, roughly 1500-year-old California Redwood tree for 738 days between December 10, 1997 and December 18, 1999. Hill lived in the tree, affectionately known as "Luna," to prevent Pacific Lumber Company loggers from cutting it down. This workshop took place at HSU only 3 months after her tree sit. Included in this footage is the tree sit, the team that helped support the activism, and Julia's account of her experience.

Title: Julia Butterfly Hill workshop
Description:
Description: Julia "Butterfly" Hill is an environmental activist best known for having lived in a 180-foot-tall, roughly 1500-year-old California Redwood tree for 738 days between December 10, 1997 and December 18, 1999. Hill lived in the tree, affectionately known as "Luna," to prevent Pacific Lumber Company loggers from cutting it down. This workshop took place at HSU only 3 months after her tree site. Included on this footage is the tree sit, the team that helped support the activism, and Julia's account of her experience. Included on this tape are introductions from HSU professors and Hill recounting her experience.

Call Number: Video 3900

Source: 1 Tape of 1: 1/2 inch videotape

Title: Gearhart - Marsh
Description:
Description: Robert Gearhart is an Environmental Engineering Emeritus Professor at Humboldt State University. He worked closely with George Allen to collaborate with the City of Arcata and Humboldt State University to create the internationally recognized artificial marsh wastewater treatment system which is part of the Arcata Marsh and Wildlife Sanctuary (AMWS). These two unedited tapes are a continuous interview with Gearhart as he guides the filmmakers through the marsh.

Title: Quake '92
Description:
Note: Program ends at 00:08:00, followed by unrelated content.

Description: On April 25-26, 1992, three powerful earthquakes (magnitudes 7.1, 6.6, and 6.7) struck the rural Humboldt County area on the northwest coast of California. With their epicenters offshore, south of Petrolia, this earthquake created a great deal of damage to the small towns of the area, including Ferndale, Fortuna, Petrolia, Rio Dell, and Scotia. Local Cameraman Ross Rowley was filming a "Best of the West Festival" in the streets of Ferndale and had his camera rolling when the earthquake struck. He filmed during the earthquake, the aftermath, and held on the ground interviews with residents.

Source: 1 Tapes of 1: 3/4 inch videotape

Title: [Congressman Clausen's Film on M-16 Rifle]
Description:
Description: This is footage of Congressman Don Clausen talking with a Captain who is serving in Vietnam. They discuss weapons used in action and their country of origin. There is also a discussion of motivation of Viet Cong. Congressman Clausen is then at his desk explain the shortage of gun cleaning supplies in Vietnam and the controversy over the M-16 rifle.
Note on can: ~15 min DHC talking w/ Capt. Carrol (sp?) who has been in VN. Weapons used in VN & country of origin: chez, USSR, NVN, China. Discussion of motivation of V Cong. DHC at his desk: re: shortage of gun cleaning supplies in VN. controversy over M-16 rifle.

Source: 1 Reel of 1: Film: 16mm

Title: Humboldt State College Sweethearts Ball
Description:
Description: The Sweethearts Ball was held at the Municipal Auditorium in Eureka, California on February 14, 1947. This formal dance was the social highlight of the Arcata-Eureka social season.
Note in can: 10 minute reel of "Sweethearts Ball", Municipal Auditorium, 14 Feb 1947. Harold Tupper, President of the Freshman Class, Humboldt State College, which sponsored this formal dance, was the organizer and guiding spirit of the (social highlight) of the Arcata-Eureka social season. (Reel taken by Ellis Williamson)

Title: 1964 Flood/Dedication of Tunnel Highway 199
Description:
Note: Silent until 00:12:50. Silent again 00:37:00 to the end.

Description: Two films are on one 16mm reel. The first features aerial footage of the 1964 Flood. The Christmas Flood of 1964 was a major disaster affecting much of the Pacific Northwest. The second film is the dedication of the Tunnel on CA Route 199, known as the Redwood Highway, near the Oregon border. Present at the dedication are Senators Clair Engle and Randolph Collier.
Note in can: 1) 1964 Flood - Appears to have been shot a day or two after flood - Eel River, Highway 101, Pepperwood, Scotia Lumber, bridges, farms, etc. 2) Dedication of tunnel Highway 199, Cal/Ore. Senators Claire Engle, Randolph Collier.

Title: The Best Years: Kate Buchanan with Homer Balabanis
Description:
Description: Professor Homer Balabanis taught economics at HSU from 1923-1963. This footage features Balabanis speaking with Kate Buchanan, who came to HSU in 1946 as assistant professor of English and Speech. She eventually became Dean of Women (a title that would later be changed to "associate dean of activities"), and helped overturn the rules that females could not wear slacks.

Source: 1 Tapes of 1: 3/4 inch videotape

Title: Keeping the World in Balance: Talks with the Artist Brian Tripp
Description: Note: Program begins at 00:00:45. Audio is L channel only. Description: Brian Tripp is a well known Karuk artist whose work has been featured throughout the United States and abroad. A traditional dancer and singer, he is actively involved in the ceremonies of northwest California and is deeply committed to Native American sovereignty and to the struggle this involves. On this tape, the artist discusses himself and his work as a tribal person without a homeland, focusing on the Native American cultural influence on his art. Title: Klamath/Trinity Fisheries - A Native American Perspective
Description: Note: Video is quite dark as in original recording. Description: Fishery resources issues viewed from a traditional Indian perspective and the relationship to government policy, followed by a panel presentation on ceremonies as the center of Indian culture and fish as the central focus of ceremonies to explain spiritual aspects of fishery management in Native American culture in Northern California. Tape 1: Sovereignty of the Klamath and Trinity River Indians / Amos Tripp, The Spirit of the fish / Jack Norton Tape 2: Panel discussion on Indian ceremonies. Title: Redwood Region Deer Herds
Description: Note: Warning - most of this film involves a deer dissection. Description: A study of Humboldt County blacktail deer by HSU wildlife researchers revealing the current status of these deer, providing baseline data against which future studies can be compared as a way to judge changes and trends of deer in Humboldt County. Footage is shown of procedures used in gathering the results of outdoor field autopsy and lab autopsy to determine physical condition, reproductive status, and parasite burdens. The three study areas are: Big Lagoon, Kneeland Area, Kings Range Conservation Area. Source: 1 Reel of 1: Film: 16mm Rights: Copyrighted. Rights are owned by Humboldt State University. Title: Federal Indian Law
Description: Note: Speaker is dark, but slides are fully lit, as on original recording. Description: In 1966, Humboldt State University (HSU) established the Center for Community Development (CCD) to provide services and outreach to American Indian communities in Indian Country on behalf of HSU. The name was changed to the Center for Indian Community Development (CICD) in 1991; CICD closed in 2013. These videos document the Center's discussions with Native American leaders and artists about their perceptions of culture and community. Source: 3 Tapes of 3: 1/2 inch videotape Rights: Copyrighted. Title: Alternative Review with Julia Butterfly Hill and Mark Sommer
Description: Description: This is an audio recording of the KHSU program Alternative Review, which features in-depth interviews with pioneers on the frontiers of cultural transformation, individuals who are discovering more effective and humane responses to the most profound and persistent challenges of our time. Julia "Butterfly" Hill is an environmental activist best known for having lived in a 180-foot-tall, roughly 1500-year-old California Redwood tree for 738 days between December 10, 1997 and December 18, 1999. Hill lived in the tree, affectionately known as "Luna," to prevent Pacific Lumber Company loggers from cutting it down. This interview is from atop Luna. Julia speaks about what she learned in her nine months in that ancient redwood. Title: The Women's Show - Interview with Paula Gunn Allen
Description: Note: Spoken sections appear only in the left channel, as on original tapes. Music segments are recorded at low level. Description: Paula Gunn Allen (October 24, 1939 - May 29, 2008) was a Native American poet, literary critic, lesbian activist, and novelist. In addition to her literary work, in 1986 she published a major study on the role of women in American Indian traditions, arguing that Europeans had de-emphasized the role of women in their accounts of native life because of their own patriarchal societies. It stimulated other scholarly work by feminist and Native American writers. Additional Description: Notes on original containers: Tape 1 - Incue (first sound of program) "Welcome to lesbian concentrate!" Outcue - song-it's the ancestors breath-ah ah ah. Length of reel - 67' 46' 01:38:19 Producer Belle Shalom Production date May '85. Tape 2 - Incue - "who are you writing for?" outcue - song-piano- Beth York. Rights: Copyrighted. Title: Grace Paley, Dick Day and Herbert Gold discussion
Description:
Note: Due to original recording: begins and ends abruptly.

Description: Grace Paley is one of the great American short-story writers. Her Collected Stories was a finalist for both the Pulitzer Prize and the National Book Award. From 1986 to 1988, Ms. Paley was New York's first official state author; she was also a past poet laureate of Vermont. Herbert Gold is an author known was part of the literary crowd of the Beat Generation. His papers are held at the Bancroft Library. Richard Dick Day began teaching at Humboldt State University in 1959. In the 1960s and 1970s, he was instrumental in bringing major poets and writers to teach and read at Humboldt.

Title: Laurie Simmons, Michael Kagen, Alison Lima
Description:
Note: Due to original recording: static and interference. Content warning: sexual assault and violence discussed.

Description: Laurie Simmons is an American artist, photographer and filmmaker. Since the mid-1970s, Simmons has staged scenes for her camera with dolls, ventriloquist dummies, objects on legs, and people, to create photographs that reference domestic scenes. She is part of The Pictures Generation, a name given to a group of artists from a 2009 exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. Michael Kagen and Alison Lima are local artists.

Title: Brian Tripp
Description:
Description: Brian Tripp is a well known Karuk artist whose work has been featured throughout the United States and abroad. A traditional dancer and singer, he is actively involved in the ceremonies of northwest California and is deeply committed to Native American sovereignty and to the struggle this involves. Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/522358.

Born in the middle of the 20th century, Alice Walker is an American writer, poet and activist. In 1982 she became the first african american woman to win a pulitzer prize for fiction for her book The Color Purple which is now a film and broadway musical. She has an abundance of awards and honors to her name including the Domestic Human Rights Award and an honorary degree from the California Institute of the Arts.

Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/522360.

Born at the start of the 19th century, Edgar AllenPoe was an American writer, poet and literary critic. He is considered the inventor of the detection fiction genre, contributor to science fiction genre and the leader of the Romanticism movement in the United States. He is now remembered in the Hall of Fame and the Mystery Writers of America give awards in his honor.

Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/522382.

First published in 1936, Kenneth Patchen was an American poet and novelist. Throughout his career he pushed himself to discover more experimental styles and forms of writing. Along with Langston Hughes and Kenneth Rexroth they established a genre known as jazz poetry. An archive of his work is kept at the University of California Santa Cruz. His final home is in the San Francisco Bay Area where he continues to host jazz poetry events based on his work.

He also helped to discover and shape the work of James Joyce, Ernest Hemingway and T.S. Eliot. In 1949 he won the Bollingen Prize for Poetry.

Adrienne Rich was an American poet, essayist and feminist. She was renowned as one of the most influential poets of the late 20th century. She was also credited with combining the topic of women and lesbians oppression with poetic discourse. She won the National Book Award, the Griffin Poetry Prize, the Bollinger Prize and the Guggenheim fellowship among others throughout her life. She taught at several universities all over the country in the writing division, eventually moving to Santa Cruz, CA where she stayed until her death.

In his retirement he moved to Berkeley and was a visiting professor at the University of California Berkeley until his death.

He attended San Francisco State University where he earned a degree in literature and published his first short story. He then won a writing fellowship to Stanford University. Throughout his lifetime he won over a dozen awards including the National Medal of Arts, the Governor's Arts Awards and the National Humanities Medal. He was also recognized as a subject of a 2023 USPS Forever stamp from the Black Heritage series.

Grace Paley was an author, professor, feminist and anti-war activist. Her Jewish heritage is shown in her writing through Yiddish dialogue. Writing only essays and short stories, Paley won a Guggenheim Fellowship, the Edith Wharton Award certification of merit and the O’henry Award. Stephen Miller hosted and recorded a reading series at Jambalaya, a popular Arcata, California concert venue where Paley was a guest.

Charley Burns (Yurok) is from the Humboldt County, Klamath River areas. Charley is known for his vibrant pen and ink illustrations, often collaborating with fellow artists like Brain Tripp and is an active participant in the cultural ceremonies of his people. By digitizing Burns’ interviews, speeches and art demonstrations will contribute to the preservation of indigenous knowledge and art. Brian Tripp was a prolific artist, poet, and activist as well as a member of the Karuk Tribe. His contributions to these fields were not only appreciated locally but also by national and international institutions and individuals.

H.D. "Timm" Williams (Yurok) was a Native American activist involved with the "Indians of All Tribes" occupation at Alcatraz. He served on the United Indian Health Services Board and as Chairman of the California Rural Indian Health Board. He performed as Prince Lightfoot, the Stanford University mascot, for 20+ years.

Julian Lang (Karuk and Wiyot) is a storyteller, poet, artist, graphic designer, and writer. He is a first language speaker of Karuk and a tribal scholar. Julian is a member of the Board of Directors of the Ink People- Center for Arts and the author of Ararapikva: Karuk Indian Literature from Northwest California. His work reaches beyond the local community to provide knowledge and art about the Karuk and Wiyot people to the rest of the world.

Title: Hoopa Brush Dance 1957
Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578909.

Hoopa Brush Dance demonstration in 1957. The Brush dance is traditionally performed by the Yurok, Hupa and Karuk tribes of the Klamath/Trinity watershed as a curing ceremony for a sick child in the community. The Dance is traditionally held around a fire in the central pit of a redwood plank house that has had its roof and walls removed.

The first annual Humboldt State University Pow-Wow and social gathering was in 1991. Historically this was a celebration held in the spring to celebrate the beginning of renewal of life. It brought people together to sing and dance as well as make new friends and renew old friendships.

The Native American Career Education in Natural Resources (NACENR) was the first of its kind in the country, focusing on bolstering diversity in STEM. Established in 1972, this organization has continued to expand their goal to serve all underrepresented students pursuing degrees in STEM. The vision and methods embraced by the program remain rooted in the integration of indigenous peoples’ knowledge with mainstream science.

Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578919.

Walt Bresette was a member of the Red Cliff Band of Lake Superior Ojibwe and a long-time treaty rights and environmental activist, author, artist, storyteller, organizer and public speaker. The Humboldt County Green Party and the Institute of Native Knowledge in conjunction with the then named Humboldt State University, hosted an event at which Walt Bresette performed.

Title: Indian Child Welfare Tape Pete Nix + Mon
Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578920.

The Indian Child Welfare Act (ICWA) was enacted in 1978 in response to a crisis affecting American Indian and Alaska Native children, families, and tribes. Studies revealed that large numbers of Native children were being separated from their parents, extended families, and communities by state child welfare and private adoption agencies. Congressional testimony documented the devastating impact this was having upon Native children, families, and tribes. The intent of Congress under ICWA was to “protect the best interests of Indian children and to promote the stability and security of Indian tribes and families” (25 U.S.C. § 1902).

Title: The Life of Jim DeMulling
Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578930.

Jim DeMulling was a timber faller for the Pacific Lumber Company and others, and then later an activist. DeMulling was worried about the environment and was involved in the ad hoc group that opposed herbicide spraying in 1977. DeMulling is noted to have created the name for the organization, the Environmental Protection Information Center (EPIC).

Title: Klamath Watershed
Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578937.

The Klamath Watershed covers 9.4 million acres and is home to six federally-recognized tribes; The Yurok, Karuk, Hoopa, Shasta, and Klamath tribes plus Quartz Valley Indian Reservation and the Resighini Rancheria, who lived off and tended to the land for thousands of years before European colonization. Today, Tribal nations control approximately 10% of the watershed while 60% is managed by public agencies like the National Park Service and 30% is privately owned. This watershed is crucial in providing water to the region and demonstrates a rich history of environmental activism and land and water rights disputes.

He served on the United Indian Health Services Board and as Chairman of the California Rural Indian Health Board. He performed as Prince Lightfoot, the Standford University mascot, for 20+ years.

Title: The HSU Natural History Museum
Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578952.

The Natural History Museum of Cal Poly Humboldt exhibits a world-class collection of over 2,000 fossils as well as displays on local natural history. There are many opportunities for students to have internships or participate in different activities at the museum. Covering topics from local history to biodiversity and providing various interactive elements, the Museum also attracts tourists and community members.

Description:

The Klamath Watershed covers 9.4 million acres and is home to six federally-recognized tribes; The Yurok, Karuk, Hoopa, Shasta, and Klamath tribes plus Quartz Valley Indian Reservation and the Resighini Rancheria, who lived off and tended to the land for thousands of years before European colonization. Today, Tribal nations control approximately 10% of the watershed while 60% is managed by public agencies like the National Park Service and 30% is privately owned. This watershed is crucial in providing water to the region and demonstrates a rich history of environmental activism and land and water rights disputes. The fish kills in the 2000s made national news and became an activism focal point.

Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578961.

Betty Chinn grew up homeless in China and escaped during the Cultural Revolution. Since her escape, for the past 25 years she has been a tireless advocate and caretaker to Humboldt County's homeless and underserved populations. Twice a day, nearly 365 days a year, Betty delivers meals and coffee to hundreds of people.

Title: Voices of Humboldt County: The Cumulative Impact 1
Description:
Please visit the California Revealed website to see the most complete and up-to-date version of this object: https://californiarevealed.org/node/578875.

Filled with powerful images and interviews with local Humboldt County citizens, this informative on-the-ground video exposed the negative images of Maxxam Corporation's/Pacific Lumber Company's irresponsible logging on the slopes of California's North Coast. Downstream residents explain how logging-related disasters impact their lives and damage their property. Working together, they are exposing the cumulative impacts of reckless logging and unsustainable management. The film also delves into Maxxam's financial woes, the force driving Pacific Lumber's hasty and dangerous logging style. In this film, effects of such practices are dramatically and devastatingly clear.
Subject: c ; a ; l ; i ; f ; o ; r ; n ; i ; a ; r ; e ; v ; e ; a ; l ; e ; d
